channel.name: ظ・nova・68
channel.topic:
Introducing: NOVA ⚡️a global, decentralized engine for drug discovery
now live on #bittensor subnet 68! 

NOVA pushes virtual drug screening beyond state-of-the-art models and transforms it into a high‑speed race for breakthroughs that rewards experts and enthusiasts alike for identifying synthesizable compounds with the highest affinity for key drug targets from a billion size database. 

our subnet functions as a back to back hackathon, running 24/7. miners are encouraged to continuously develop and refine ai models and heuristic approaches that make drug hunting in a vast chemical universe more efficient.


🔗 gitHub: https://github.com/metanova-labs/nova
🔗 website: https://www.metanova-labs.com/ 

earn rewards for finding the best molecule the fastest, scoring submissions, or staking $TAO.

interested? you too can help shape the future of medicine

Hey guys!
If my calculations are correct, then by epoch 139, the entropy value will be as low as 0.007142877?
Could you explain why this update is necessary?

Don’t you think that for a broader molecular search, it would make more sense to start with higher entropy values?
For example, you could start at 1.3 and gradually lower it to 0.3 by the end

Hey 🙂
We implemented a decreasing dynamic entropy to encourage broader chemical space search in the beginning of the week, making chemical diversity matter most, and slowly decrease its importance to encourage narrowing search down to closer analogues of the most promising compounds.

The values in place right now are a canonical interval so we can get an idea of how these moving parts will interact in practice. We will probably still need to adapt the thresholds to match the values that will produce the most interesting results. We did consider starting the week with entropy weight > 1, but would like to collect some more info to choose thresholds that won't produce sets that are very diverse, but low scoring.

In terms of predictions yes, but not necessarily in terms of methods to explore the chemical universe - those should be transferable between projects and work as a way to find good and diverse entry points to modulate a target

Usually, the process to develop new drugs covers three key stages:

Hit Stage
- Activity on-target: micromolar range
- Not ideal drug properties necessarily

Key question: does the molecule modulate the target even with moderate potency?

Lead Stage
- Activity on-target: sub-micromolar to nanomolar range
- Better selectivity
- Improved solubility & stability
- Initial ADME data
Key question: Can we optimize the chemical structures?

Optimized Lead Stage
- Activity: Low nanomolar/picomolar range
- Excellent ADMET profile
- Good oral bioavailability
- Low toxicity
- Optimized physicochemical properties
Key question: Ready for clinical trials?

Important to point that the development is not uniform and the properties to be optimized are not constant across projects (some are, like toxicity and solubility, others are more dependent on the tissue to be targeted and disease to be treated). 

While one needs to first find molecules that hit the target, getting better drug-like properties early saves massive time and money.

When we start with multi-billion molecule libraries, we increase the odds of finding molecules that already have better drug properties earlier - more options correlates with better chances of finding the molecules that are gonna check many of the boxes + increases the chemical novelty factor (IP relevant)
Do you believe the current mining challenge format is optimized for the hit stage or all stages?
Right now we are covering parts of first and second stage but incentivizing the efficient exploration of huge chemical spaces is a potential unlock to optimize for all
With multi-billion searches in place, the number of models to optimize for can increase substantially
But doing many models for a lot of properties wo a relevant chemical universe would likely not be effective

@amanita | nova [τ, ظ ] @penna | NOVA @urdof | nova [τ, ظ ] Hey folks, I was wondering what are your thoughts about the structure of the results having historical data now after some time. A kind of a paradox is occurring if we observe solutions, aside from the fact that solutions are being found indeed very fast. The paradox I am referring to (at least in my mind) is the score values. Looking at the scores across a day, we can see that top miners converge to almost identical solutions. This could potentially be the case if the problem was a gradient search for a local/global maximum but is contrary to the structure of the problem "as advertised". One would think that given the vast chemical space, the number of anti-targets and the number of submission molecules that there would be high entropy in the results and potentially different scores for the submission. In reality different miners share several similar molecules (if not a whole submission-even if we account for miners sharing the same coldkey). Is this the structure that you expected from solutions? Does this fact make sense in terms of the nature of the problem?

My concern raising this is that it may be that another "meta-hacking" has been identified towards the incentives mechanism. Is there another level of verification that is being done from your side with respect to the quality of the solutions? Do the submissions make sense from a physicochemical perspective?
E.g. the last epoch's top scores have the same score at 4 decimal places.

We posted this to our X account yesterday, but I think it is good information to have here too. This is data for the human SERT. In blue, we took a random sample of 5 million molecules distributed accross several different properties of the dataset. In pink, it's the on-target score of miners submissions. The y-axis is the proportion of the total samples of each set. If we set 7 as the threshold to separate binders and non-binders, the pink set is enriched in over 5000%, enrichment meaning the ratio of molecules predicted as positives in the total set. 

Of course this is a model and there are certainly molecules that are false positives on the pink set, but from the perspective of the search problem being proposed, you guys are doing a pretty good job. In terms of the quality of submissions we received, the analyses we ran so far indicate that we have a good mix between molecules that are similar to other known structures that have activity over the targets and novel chemical scaffolds.

As for the speed in which answers are being submitted, my take is that the winning teams are precomputing scores for big chunks of the dataset, since the target is disclosed ~24h before the start of the competition and then run optimizations for entropy during the challenge itself. Because these groups start from the same subset of molecules, maximizing the combination of entropy and score while avoiding seen molecules tends to converge to identical or near-identical sets of molecules.

I personally think that it would be ideal to replace submission block with other tie-breaking criteria. We tested this briefly in the beginning of Shannon, but block number is what ended up working the best with the amount of identical submissions we were receiving. If we are able to remove block number as a criterion, the problem then becomes finding the best possible answer in 360 blocks, not submitting a response before everyone else, but then it doesn't work for identical answers.

This is something we aim to address with the substantial increase of the dataset to be searched. If precomputing starts becoming increasingly difficult/costly/with diminishing returns, different routes of exploration then become more worthwhile

Thank you for sharing that here as well. That is as you mentioned a single model comparing a single random sample vs more sophisticated search but is interesting indeed. 

My point/question was more on the score values themselves rather the tie-braking mechanism. Converging to the same score would be okay under quite a big assumption if I may say so. That miners start from the same subset of molecules. This is a rather big if, considering different teams and different scientific background/preprocessing regimes.

Would you be able to show a graph comparing submissions across different epochs for the same target protein for different miners and also graphs of submissions across different target proteins? The latter would be more interesting to be fair. If there's low entropy in candidate solutions across different targets that may hint at a specific bias of PSICHIC that is being exploited for instance.

That makes total sense and might lead to the development of novel models as well. Right now I am guessing most people follow what you described in the previous message, concurrent processing of target/anti-target models prior to the new target being introduced across multiple server instances.

For this version of the finetuned model, it's very likely that the highest scoring molecules accross targets share a high degree of similarity. Because DAT, SERT and NET are very similar proteins (and we're working with both mice and human versions). There are known medications that act upon different combinations of these, like bupropion, methyphenidate, venlafaxine, and many others

We’ve pushed improvments to the combinatorial database reactions, they can be found in molecules.sqlite on Hugging Face and in the ``improve_reactions`` branch on GitHub.

@nova・68  
We are adjusting miner emission rewards. 

We recognize that NOVA’s miners are the lifeblood of our subnet. Your remarkable talent and ingenuity have given incredible results for today’s challenges far faster than we anticipated. While we keep curating and expanding the dataset and preparing larger, more expensive scoring models, the current task simply doesn’t need the level of scale (or cost) that tokens are funding right now. 

We believe that to succeed long term we need to be responsible with the subnet emissions. It is not our intention to neglect the miners, but it's becoming clear that overspending with emission is unsustainable in the dTao ecosystem. We have a lot of data to work with and want to scale the subnet tempo and data collection process to demand with emissions. 

After discussing the change with miners, we believe this is a vital step in our mission to build the world's most efficient virtual screening engine together, and we will start by burning 80% of emissions. 

That being said, this change will be dynamic. We'll adjust burn as the subnet develops and workload grows with bigger models, added prediction stages, and more rigorous searches. 

To give miners time to adjust we have had discussions earlier, and will be implementing this change this coming Monday July, 21st.

embeds.description:
@nova・68 
Nous ajustons les récompenses d'émission de mineurs. 

Nous reconnaissons que les mineurs de Nova’sont l'élément vital de notre sous-réseau. Votre talent remarquable et votre ingéniosité ont donné des résultats incroyables pour les défis aujourd'hui’bien plus rapidement que prévu. Alors que nous continuons à organiser et à élargir l'ensemble de données et à préparer des modèles de notation plus grands et plus chers, la tâche actuelle n'a tout simplement pas besoin que’ne nécessite le niveau d'échelle (ou le coût) que les jetons financent dès maintenant. 

Nous pensons que pour réussir à long terme, nous devons être responsables des émissions de sous-réseau. Nous n'avons pas l'intention de négliger les mineurs, mais il devient clair que les dépenses excessives avec les émissions ne sont pas durables dans l'écosystème DTAO. Nous avons beaucoup de données avec lesquelles travailler et voulons mettre à l'échelle le processus de sous-réseau et le processus de collecte de données à exiger avec les émissions. 

Après avoir discuté du changement avec les mineurs, nous pensons qu'il s'agit d'une étape vitale dans notre mission de construire ensemble le moteur de dépistage virtuel le plus efficace du monde, et nous commencerons par brûler 80% d'émissions. 

Cela étant dit, ce changement sera dynamique. Nous ajusterons Burn à mesure que le sous-réseau se développe et que la charge de travail augmente avec des modèles plus importants, des étapes de prédiction supplémentaires et des recherches plus rigoureuses. 

Pour donner aux mineurs le temps de nous adapter, nous avons eu des discussions plus tôt et mettra en œuvre ce changement le lundi 21 juillet prochain.

I hear the concern that a burn could shrink the miner pool, but the alternative, continuing to overspend on compute simply because we can, is short sighted. Bittensor’s thesis is that the smartest, most efficient software (and hardware) wins. The teams that squeeze the most signal per GPU-hour rise to the top. Increasing efficiency through open, global competition is exactly how we can out compete our centralized competitors.

Right now some teams are burning through GPUs beyond what the current task requires. By trimming emissions, we continue to reward miners who write adaptable, resource-aware pipelines and have more room to succeed as we roll out larger models, added prediction stages, and tougher searches. We've already confirmed that some miners have the ability to stay profitable after the burn rate, giving us confidence the ecosystem will stay healthy while retaining the oportunity to scale rewards up when the workload demands it. This is about aligning miner reward with the actual needs of the subnet to create a sustainable business model. Just like compute subnets do not need thousands of idle GPUs, we do not need a solution for each challenge in 3 blocks. If this also entails an update in the incentive mechanism, we’re open to discussing it constructively, as we have many times. But we also have been very clear since the beginning of our operations that scaling hardware and brute forcing solutions was not the way to go about this problem. If you want to call this stellar performance, that’s fine with me, since the quality of the submissions is actually very good, but it is being achieved in a wasteful manner. You will need to scale down your operations and, yes, it will stop being profitable for inefficient miners, as it should. Attacking and trying to intimidate the team with lies and a smug attitude without knowing the full picture, though, is not ok. If you think our tech is this bad, feel free to open a PR, if it's actually good and useful, you may even get a bounty.

It is not our team’s job to do that math for you.

While we do appreciate the work you guys have and continue to perform, the burn is necessary to eliminate wasteful practices in operations and contribute to a sustainable business model. The output from miners is just the first step in many others involved in developing a drug candidate. Apart from more computational post-processing, there are lab validation steps that are costly and time consuming and the financial investment required for these steps will be made by us. The product of this subnet is not software, compute and staff are just a small fraction of the costs involved in our operations. We have actually come forward in many opportunities outlining the steps needed to achieve assets that can possibly be monetized much, much earlier than the traditional pharma industry.

Apart from that, miners are in a much more liquid position than we as the subnet team are, it is perfectly acceptable for miners to sell their emissions to fund operations, while subnet teams are still scrutinized if they do the same.

So, I propose solving the problem in this subnet in three stages.

Stage One – Change the incentive mechanism
Instead of asking miners to simply find the best set of molecules, you should ask them to provide the best algorithm or model that finds the best set of molecules.

Look at subnet 45. In this subnet, miners provide algorithms that perform best at solving the task. They upload their algorithms to Hugging Face. Then, a validator downloads the algorithm, runs it, and evaluates its performance. The miner whose algorithm performs best gets rewarded for a certain period, after which the competition repeats again and again.

Also, look at subnets like 11, 58, and 76. In these, miners upload ready-to-use models to Hugging Face. Validators run these models on their datasets and evaluate them. The best-performing model earns the reward.

In your current subnet, miners should submit their algorithms for finding the best molecule sets. The validator, with access to the full database of molecules, would then run the submitted algorithm, feeding it different sets of proteins (targets and anti-targets). The algorithm would, for example, select 1 million suitable molecules for each task. The validator would then get affinity score for targets and anti-targets from that million and let the algorithm choose the best 100 molecules. The validator would repeat this process 5–10 times. In the end, they’d see the overall score of the molecule set and the time the algorithm needed to complete the task. Based on this, the best algorithm would be determined.

This way, you’d always have the best algorithm in your hands, which you could use to solve as many tasks as you like, with whatever resources you consider appropriate.

You might say there are lots of nuances here—and you’d be absolutely right. But around 20% of subnets in Bittensor already use a mechanism like this. So it’s definitely possible. You just need to take the best practices from those subnets that already have experience with this evaluation model.

Stage Two – Understand why restricting miner emissions doesn’t work
Restricting miner rewards limits the number of teams willing to work on the task.

Think of esports as an example. The prize pools for games like Dota 2 or CS:GO are several million dollars. This encourages a huge number of teams worldwide to train and prepare for these tournaments. But only one team ultimately takes the prize. You can’t then say to them, “We gave you $3 million, but you only spent $100 000 preparing, so next year the prize pool will only be $150 000.” That would kill other teams’ motivation to prepare, because the tournament would no longer be worth it for them.

So, large miner rewards shouldn’t be judged solely by how much effort the winner (or a few winners) spends. The winners are just the tip of the iceberg. You also need to consider all the teams investing heavily in algorithms in hopes of winning.

Right now, miners can earn $800 000+ per month. That’s enough to attract many teams. Each team is willing to spend tens of thousands of dollars on developers and resources from their own pockets, knowing that a win will more than cover their losses and deliver profit. As a result, you could have 40 teams working on the same problem, collectively investing more than $800 000 in development and infrastructure—simply because the potential reward justifies it. But this only works if there’s a fair incentive mechanism, as described in Stage One.

Stage Three – Combine current and future approaches
If you still need miners to directly solve your tasks (for example, if you don’t want to run the algorithms yourself), you could allocate, say, 20% of emissions for miners to solve tasks you send them, and allocate the remaining 80% of emissions to rewarding the best algorithms.

Of course, the miner with the best algorithm would also use it to solve the tasks you send. This way, there’s no race for raw computational power. Over time, you could reduce that 20% to 10% or even 5%, because you’d be able to efficiently manage the resources you need—without killing miners’ motivation to keep improving algorithms for finding the best molecule sets.

messages.content: why do I get "Error initializing model for antitarget A0A8M1H0Z8: PytorchStreamReader failed reading zip archive: not a ZIP archive"?

Sometimes the model weights do not download properly from github and we recommend re-downloading for the TREAT-2 model directly from huggingface: https://huggingface.co/Metanova/TREAT-2/tree/main

you can use this command ```wget -O PSICHIC/trained_weights/TREAT2/model.pt https://huggingface.co/Metanova/TREAT-2/resolve/main/model.pt```

then try loading the model again.
only 2 miners get incentives in the subnet. Is it because they are dominating?

Last week, there were four miners. This week, 80% of their earnings were cut, and two of them left.
In addition, last week was about searching for the optimal solution among the molecules of 45B(including savi & rxn molecules). Now, the optimal solution is only searched among the molecules of 1B(only savi molecules) due to the significant loss of computing power.
@Ragman It's your show time. Big miners are scale down a lot already.
I checked out the discussion and tried it, this project’s huge and crazy complex. Why’d you call it easy?
Depends on your starting point. Existing miners found the challenge got easier over the last ten days. For someone new it’s a big challenge
Emissions are so low right now, I feel like I can’t make any money.😩
Existing miners are also did a very crazy complex job.
The rxn molecules are missing in the “optimal” solution, and the “optimal” is not optimal at all actually due to miner’s emission was decreased, and most of the power was shutdown.

And the submission molecules quantity is also decreased, only few uid submitted in each epoch.

Both quantity and quality were decreased.
But earlier they said it doesn’t need much GPU power
They know nothing about how miner works.😀

How could you find the optimal 100 molecules among 45B molecules if it doesn’t have much GPU?
This week miners are only searching among 1B molecules.
Most projects try to attract as much hash power as they can, so why is the subnet owner doing exactly the opposite here?
The owner team is keep silence.

From the very start of the subnet we always pointed how the focus should be on optimizing the search algorithms to navigate the chemical universe.

The long term vision for the subnet covers the use of models beyond psichic, and the use of combinatorial databases much larger than SAVI.

Consider different kinds of predictions and pieces of the chemical universes as variables that will keep increasing constantly, meaning that even with the dynamic nature of the implemented burn, the amount of calculation currently being employed is not optimized. We must ensure the strategies under development here are larger than PSICHIC specific and SAVI specific strategies if the idea is the long term value creation.

The burn, the recent changes and the next changes are measures that all redirect the incentives to one direction - software improvements for chemical space exploration. Me and everyone else from the subnet has been pointing this as the way to go
In the long term from day 1 of the subnet.

With that said could you please elaborate with metrics (ideally) how the quality of the data is decreasing? And how this impacts the next steps of the drug development process?

Subnet owners must have vision that encompasses mining and other steps, while doing everything in the most efficient way.
On that I agree with you, that’s is not an easy task. It is a super competitive one and we must ensure the competition is generating value as a highly scalable and flexible drug screening platform

Did you noticed that the rxn molecules are not included in the miner’s submission of past 20-30 epochs? And only savi molecules were included.
This means miners only searching “optimal” submission among 1B molecules, not among 45B molecules.
SAVI was being heavily prioritized prior to the burn implementation.
So do you means 44B rxn molecules are not important? Or not very important?
No
I don’t mean that
Now miners are not searching the best optimal among 44B molecules.
submission were enriched in an unproportional way with savi molecules prior to the burn
They cut the power due to the decrease of miner’s emission.
It seems I don't get your point.

And how this impacts the next steps of the drug development process?
---
I'm not clear about this aspect. I know very little about chemistry. All I know is that the search space for the optimal solution has changed from 45B to 1B.
And in the previous optimal solution combination, out of 100 molecules, approximately 20% to 30% of the molecules were rxn molecules.
Yeah, we were getting less (proportionally) than one would expect from rxn previously
If you think the optimal solution found among 1B savi molecules is sufficient for your use, then I have nothing more to suggest.

If that's the case, we will use a small number of cards to claim this small amount of reward, just as using this small amount of salary to help you find some molecules.  In most cases, this is not the optimal solution and there won't be much innovation throughout the project. And it's very difficult for new miners to get in.

First of all I appreciate we being able to discuss in a more respectful way. 

Second, we again strongly advise you to direct your efforts to solutions that are not psichic and savi dependent. We are saying this openly since subnet day 1.

You guys have been able to achieve a lot finding the shortest paths to the answer for sure in ingenious ways.

But please do not ignore the direction we are literally saying is the one we are going to be using to shape the subnet to go from great answers to even better ones.
This is your unilateral idea. If you only give miner a little reward, in the absence of competition, miner won't give you the so-called "great answers".
@lazycat what’s your vision on the great discussions happening in the church of rao channel regarding voting power for burn based on amount of tokens being hold?

I just want to be fair. It's fine to destroy the miner, but why don't the validator and owner be destroyed? If the bittensor network is unable to destroy the tokens of the validator and owner, you can manually go to the black hole address.
@!      distributed_tensor [τ, γ] is beautifully articulating on how this can be the way to solve for it

I know how it's being done at the moment. I saw it in the code. The portion that should have been 100% given to miner is now 20% given to miner, and the remaining 80% is given to an address held by the owner. Whether this 80% will be destroyed in the future is actually not very convincing.
There might be a misunderstanding from your side here.
